video.title_en: The Amazing Life and Strange Death of Captain Cook

summary.text_en: Captain James Cook, a British explorer and cartographer, commanded three monumental voyages to the Pacific. On his *first* voyage (1768-1771), he created the first complete map of *New Zealand* and, in 1770, landed on the east coast of *Australia*, naming it 'New South Wales' and claiming it for Britain. His voyages were models of *scientific exploration*, carrying astronomers and botanists (like Joseph Banks). He was also the first to successfully prevent *Scurvy* on a long voyage through diet (like sauerkraut) and the first to use a 'Marine Chronometer' to accurately calculate *longitude* at sea.
key_points_en: Charted New Zealand and East Coast of Australia (1770)
First to practically solve the 'Longitude Problem' (with a chronometer)
First to conquer 'Scurvy' on a long voyage (with diet/Vitamin C)
First to cross the 'Antarctic Circle' (Second Voyage)

story.text_en:
Cook's voyages were the 'Apollo Missions' of the 18th century. His *First Voyage* (1768-71) had a public mission: sail to Tahiti to observe the 'Transit of Venus' (`transit_of_venus_1761`), an astronomical task. His *secret* orders: find the mythical 'Terra Australis Incognita'. He didn't find *that*, but he *did* systematically map New Zealand and Australia's east coast with near-modern precision.
On his *Second Voyage* (1772-75), he carried a copy (K1) of John Harrison's (`harrison_chronometer_1761`) 'marine chronometer'. This 'clock' allowed him to *know his longitude* (East-West position) accurately for the first time. Using this, he deliberately sailed south *into* the ice, becoming the first human to cross the Antarctic Circle, proving the 'great southern continent' was a frozen wasteland. He solved the longitude problem and the southern continent myth in one go.

fun_facts.text_en: Cook famously prevented scurvy by *forcing* his men to eat 'sauerkraut' (rich in Vitamin C). As a result, he didn't lose a single man to the disease on his first voyage, a feat then unheard of.
His ship was a floating laboratory. On the *Endeavour*, the botanist Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander collected over 3,000 plant species.
Cook was killed in 1779 during his Third Voyage, in a skirmish with the islanders of Hawaii (which he had named the 'Sandwich Islands').

simple_explanation.text_en:
Imagine a world map from 1770 where 'Australia' and 'New Zealand' are just big blank smudges.
Captain James Cook was the man who took a 'science ship' to 'fill in those blanks'. He was like Captain Kirk of the *Enterprise*, on a mission to 'explore new worlds' and 'map the stars' (or in his case, the oceans).
He succeeded because of two things:
1. He had a **super-watch** (the 'Chronometer', `harrison_chronometer_1761`), which, for the first time, let him know *exactly where he was* East-to-West.
2. He had **sauerkraut**, which, for the first time, kept his *crew alive* from scurvy.

applications.title: ç°ä»£åˆ¶å›¾å­¦ (Cartography)
applications.text_en: Cook's maps of the Pacific were the 'gold standard' for over a century and form the basis of all modern geography of the region.

applications.title: è§£å†³äº†â€œç»åº¦é—®é¢˜â€
applications.text_en: His practical use of the chronometer (`harrison_chronometer_1761`) *proved* longitude could be known, transforming maritime navigation from guesswork into a safe, reliable science.

applications.title: é¢„é˜²åè¡€ç—… (Scurvy Prevention)
applications.text_en: His experiments (though he misattributed the cure to 'freshness' not Vitamin C) proved scurvy was a *dietary deficiency*, not a disease, saving countless lives and building on the work of `lind_scurvy_1747`.

impact.text_en: James Cook's voyages were the Enlightenment in action. He transformed exploration from a quest for 'gold and spices' into a quest for 'scientific knowledge'. He 'completed the map' of the world, solved the 'longitude problem', and conquered 'scurvy'. His work (and that of his onboard scientists like Joseph Banks) founded the fields of biogeography and ethnography, and directly inspired the next generation of scientific explorers, most notably Humboldt (`humboldt_isotherms_1817`) and Darwin (`darwin_origin_of_species_1859`).

influenced_by.contribution_en: John Harrison (his 'marine chronometer' was the *tool* Cook needed to solve longitude)
Edmond Halley (his advocacy for observing the 'Transit of Venus' was the 'scientific motive' for the first voyage)
James Lind (his clinical trial on citrus fruits was the basis for Cook's dietary reforms)

influenced.contribution_en: Alexander von Humboldt (his model of the 'scientific explorer' was directly inspired by Cook and Banks)
Charles Darwin (his voyage on the *Beagle* was the direct methodological and spiritual successor to Cook's voyages)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Captain James Cook turned 'exploration' into 'science', and used a clock and sauerkraut to 'fill in the map' of the last unknown ocean.

quiz.question_en: What were James Cook's two great *practical* contributions to maritime navigation?
options_en: Inventing the telescope and the compass
Proving the Earth was round and inventing the steamboat
Proving 'scurvy' was preventable with diet (sauerkraut) and *practically* using the 'chronometer' to find longitude
quiz.explanation_en: Cook's voyages were the first in history where the crew *didn't* die of scurvy (`lind_scurvy_1747`) and the captain *always* knew his exact location (`harrison_chronometer_1761`). These two breakthroughs made long-distance, predictable ocean exploration possible.
